facts.text: Appellant, respondent No. 1 and respondent No. 3 were candidates for the general seat in Daspalla double-member constituency (one seat reserved for scheduled caste) in Orissa Legislative Assembly election.
Appellant obtained 17,700 votes, respondent No. 1 obtained 15,568 votes, respondent No. 3 obtained 3,589 votes.
Election held on February 27, 1957; appellant declared elected on March 5, 1957.

Respondent No. 1 filed election petition questioning appellant's election on various grounds including improper acceptance of respondent No. 3's nomination as he was Sarbarakar of 10 villages in Nayagarh district (disqualified as office of profit).
Election Tribunal, Puri, dismissed petition on October 26, 1957, holding no grounds established.
Respondent No. 1 appealed to Orissa High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 194 of 1957.
High Court held respondent No. 3 disqualified but acceptance of nomination did not materially affect appellant's election under cl. d of sub-s. 1 of s. 100 of Representation of the People Act, 1951.
High Court considered corrupt practices: bribery (not established), false statements in pamphlet Exbt. 8 (not established), obtaining assistance from Sarpanches under s.123(7)(f) (held established).
High Court set aside appellant's election, held it resulted in disqualification under s.140 but recommended removal by Election Commission under s.144.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 133(1)(c), though doubt raised.
Supreme Court granted special leave under Art. 136 as point of law of considerable public importance.

legal_issues.text: Whether a Sarpanch of a Grama Panchayat constituted under the Orissa Grama Panchayats Act, 1948 is a person in the service of the Government and belongs to the class of revenue officers including village accountants such as patwaris, lekhpals, talatis, karnams and the like under s.123(7)(f) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951.
Whether acceptance of respondent No. 3's nomination materially affected the election under s.100(1)(d) RPA 1951.
Whether Art. 133(1)(c) applies for certificate of appeal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Sarpanch not in service of Government: elected by Grama Panchayat (elected by Grama Sasan), acts under authority of Grama Panchayat, no remuneration from Government, removal only for negligence/inefficiency/misbehaviour (not conclusive); akin to Municipality Chairman.
Even if in service, Sarpanch not revenue officer or village accountant under cl.f.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.123(7)(f)

respondent_arguments.text: Sarpanch in service of Government: exercises governmental functions (collection of taxes, maintenance of accounts), under control/supervision of State Government/DM/SDM, removable by Government; 'in service of Government' wider than 'serving under'; read 'and' as 'or' before classes in s.123(7).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Orissa Grama Panchayats Act, 1948 (various ss.10,11,14,16,17,22,32,35,36,44,97,98,99); Representation of the People Act, 1951 s.123(7)

respondent_arguments.text: Respondent No. 3 disqualified as Sarbarakar (office of profit under State).

court_reasoning.text: Distinction between 'serving under' (pre-amendment s.123(8)) and 'in the service of the Government' (post-amendment s.123(7)); latter imports master-servant relationship with right of control.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No provisions of Orissa Act indicate Sarpanch in service of Government; elected, no pay from Govt, acts under Panchayat.

court_reasoning.text: Control/supervision by Govt over Panchayat administrative functions does not make it or Sarpanch in Govt service; akin to Municipalities, Co-op societies, Companies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grama Panchayat autonomous body corporate exercising statutory functions.

court_reasoning.text: Sarpanch neither revenue officer nor village accountant; s.31 contractual, not obligatory; no positive revenue functions assigned.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cl.f requires both in service AND in specified class.

court_reasoning.text: High Court erred; no corrupt practice under s.123(7)(f); other corrupt practices not established.
Resp3 disqualified but no material effect on election.

holdings.text: Sarpanch of Grama Panchayat under Orissa Act is not a person in the service of the Government nor a revenue officer/village accountant under s.123(7)(f) RPA 1951.
No corrupt practice established; election valid.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs improper acceptance of nomination, corrupt practice of obtaining assistance from specified govt servants, disqualification and removal thereof.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Grama Panchayats Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines status, election, duties, control over Grama Panchayat/Sarpanch; court analyzed to determine if Sarpanch in govt service.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; special leave granted.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Illustrative of govt control without implying service relationship.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Grama Panchayat members deemed public servants.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed with costs; High Court judgment set aside; election petition dismissed as no corrupt practice under s.123(7) established.

key_quotes.text: "there is a distinction between 'serving under the Government' and 'in the service of the Government'... the latter... imports the relationship of master and servant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core distinction leading to holding that Sarpanch not in govt service.

key_quotes.text: "It is this right of control or interference... which is the dominant characteristic in this relation and marks off the servant from an independent contractor."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines master-servant test applied to Sarpanch.

key_quotes.text: "the mere power of control and supervision of a Grama Panchayat exercising administrative functions would not make the Grama Panchayat or any of its members a person in the service of the Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
